data.text: Index
Appendix 1 – The Selection Process for Day Surgery Appendix 2 – Ophthalmic Emergencies In working hours Appendix 3 – Ophthalmic Emergencies Out Of Hours Appendix 4 – Elective Flows
Appendix 5 – Elective Day Case
Appendix 6 – Elective Inpatients
Appendix 7 – Pain Flows
Appendix 8 – Medical Records Flow
Appendix 9 – Staffing
Appendix  – Responsibilities
Appendix  – Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose

The purpose of this document is to outline how the Theatre Admission and Day Stay unit (TADSU), the Day Stay Unit (DSU) and Braintree Unit which are part of the Theatre and outpatient's directorate within the Trust, will provide the best care possible for the patient undergoing a surgical procedure within Theatres, the DSU and Braintree Unit from admission to discharge.
TADSU incorporates Recovery Room 2 within Main theatres.
The DSU is a Satellite Unit with 3 theatres and an integrated  bedded recovery area.
Braintree Unit has two theatres and 11 trolley bays. There is an area on the ward which accommodates 6 patients sitting in chairs; these are usually allocated to Ophthalmology.
Aims of the Service

To provide a service for adults who are to be admitted for a planned surgical procedure who meet the Day Stay criteria in accordance with Day Stay guidelines to be admitted for a surgical procedure and return home on the same day.
To provide patient centred care where patients receive treatment that is suited to their needs.
To reduce waiting times and improve throughput of patients.
To provide an efficient and effective service delivering a high standard of patient care.
The TADSU and DSU aim to work within the Association for Perioperative Practice (APP) and British Association of Day Surgery (BADs) guidelines ensuring a high standard of care is maintained.
Scope of the Service
TADSU is located in Recovery 2 within Main Theatres will admit patients for theatre who require admission to the main wards post surgery. The unit will be open from 07:00 to 21:00 five days a week.
Within DSU there is a service provision for three Day Surgery Theatres and facilities to accommodate patients from 07:00 on a Monday morning to 21:30 Friday.
The scope of this service extends to Mayflower Ward and the Plastic Trauma Unit; which manages patients having elective and urgent day surgery.

(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Peri-operative ward management of day case hand surgery patients (including trauma patients) receiving brachial block anaesthesia for surgery'; register number 11058)
Inclusion
(Refer to Appendix 1)
(Refer to BADS Directory of Procedures)
3.5.1 All adults who are to be admitted for a planned surgical procedure and require overnight stays will be transferred post surgery to a main ward.
3.5.2 All patients that meet the Day stay criteria will be accommodated on TADSU, DSU and operated on in the Day stay theatres according to national day stay guidelines and where capacity allows.
(Refer to Appendix 1)
Exclusions for the TADSU and DSU (Refer to BADS Directory of Procedures)

Aim is to avoid cancellation on a day of surgery if we have adequate resources such as equipment, help from floating floor consultant anaesthetist, and adequately trained staff. Final anaesthetic decision should be made by consultant anaesthetist on the day for the list.
No specific age / ASA but we should exclude
Day Stay is not suitable for emergency patients requiring a hospital stay who do not meet the day stay criteria (Refer to Appendix 1)
All Adults who are to be admitted for a planned surgical procedure and require overnight stay will be transferred to an appropriate ward for further post-op care
Patients who are at risk of falls are not suitable for admission to the DSU
Patients with severe dementia are not suitable for admission to the DSU
Patients requiring a side room are not suitable for the DSU
Patients diagnosed with diarrhoea and vomiting are not suitable for admission to the DSU
Any admission to the DSU ward must not compromise the elective admission process without the approval of the Executive on call
Patients with severe learning difficulties, predicted or previous difficult airway
The Day Stay Unit will not be used as a contingency ward for medical and surgical patients that require emergency treatment and therefore do not meet the Day Stay criteria
Patients are not to be accommodated on the Day Stay Unit as part of escalation plan or to be used as a holding area without a fixed discharge time
Intensive care patients or paediatric patients are excluded from DSU
3.6.3  TADSU
All patients that are emergencies will be excluded from TADSU

Note:  Any patient with any of exclusion criteria, who is to be scheduled for day surgery (TADSU, DSU) has to be consulted with Lead for Day Surgery or Consultant Anaesthetist covering the list and it is upon his/her discretion to schedule the procedure.
Work Flows
General Emergency Flows
4.1.1 The Day Stay team will provide a 24-hour emergency ophthalmic service within Main Theatre.

4.1.2 Many urgent operations that can be arranged in 12-24 hours may be suitable for surgery within the day surgery theatres if these patients meet the Day Stay criteria and can be accommodated in the post operatively.
4.1.3 For ophthalmic emergencies refer to Appendices 2 &
4.1.4 In case of using DSU as a contingency ward prior approval of the site manager must be sought and elective DSU operating lists should have appropriate arrangements.
Elective Flows
(Refer to Appendices 4, 5 & 6)
4.2.1 No TCI date should be given until agreed by the pre-assessment for DSU
4.2.2 If patient doesn't meet the DSU criteria, surgery should be performed in main theatres via admission through TADSU

4.2.3 Management of the Day Surgery and 23 hour waiting lists is a partnership between individual directorates, Consultant surgeons and the DSU management. Management of the main theatre waiting lists is a partnership between individual directorates, Consultant surgeons and the Theatre management.
4.2.4 Letters confirming time and date of admission will be sent with appropriate pre operative instructions and general information a minimum of 2 weeks prior to admission.

4.2.5 Pre-operative investigations will be arranged at pre assessment. Including all screening as per Trust policy. Thus, patients who are low risk or not staying in hospital overnight do not need to be screened for MRSA.
4.2.6 Prior to the patient's admission notes, x rays and investigations will be obtained.

4.2.7 Confirmation by the patient should be received at least 2 days prior to surgery, any patients failing to confirm will be contacted by telephone where possible. A second appointment will be sent to patients who do not attend. Should a patient fail to attend a second appointment, a letter will be sent to the patient, GP and consultant surgeon confirming the non-attendance.
4.2.8 Non-attendance may result in the patient being removed from the waiting list.
4.2.9 Each patient will be prepared and assessed by a named nurse who has expert knowledge of the surgical pathway and the concept of day stay.
Admission Pathway for TADSU and DSU
4.3.1 The patient will be admitted from 7:00 am.
4.3.2 The patient will be prepared for surgery as per the admission protocol.
4.3.3 If any criteria are not met, the surgeon and anaesthetist will be informed and appropriate action taken.
4.3.4 The patient will be reviewed by the Anaesthetist.
4.3.5 The patient will be reviewed by the surgeon who will mark the operation site if applicable and ensure the consent form is correct and signed.

4.3.6 A team brief will be held at 08.30 am prior to the start of the list. All key members of the operating team should be available to discuss any issues or raise concerns regarding the list order, patients, content and equipment required.
4.3.7 The first patient will be sent for after the team brief.
4.3.8 The patient will either walk to Theatre or be transferred on an operating trolley to the designated theatre.
4.3.9 All relevant documentation must be completed before entering theatre according to the WHO surgical safety checklist.
4.3.10 The patient will be checked into theatre using the WHO surgical safety checklist.
4.3.11 The transfer and positioning of the patient on the operating trolley will be in accordance with Health and safety guidelines.
4.3.12 The patient will be monitored according to the Royal College of Anaesthetist and Association of Anaesthetists guidelines.
Stage 1 Recovery Pathway for the inpatient and day case patient admitted via TADSU
4.4.1 Each patient will be allocated to a member of staff experienced in stage 1 recovery, who will remain with the patient until they are fully conscious and stable.
4.4.2 A detailed handover will be given to the recovery practitioner by the Anaesthetist.
4.4.3 The Scrub Nurse will hand over the details of the procedure to the recovery practitioner.
4.4.4 Monitoring of the patients' observations will be undertaken and pain assessed using the Aldrete score.
4.4.5 Modified Aldrete Scoring System.

table_items.text: 2 Able to deep breath and cough freely

data.text: 4.4.6 A score >/= 9 is required for discharge from first stage recovery.
4.4.7 Any abnormal observations including reports of excessive pain, bleeding, nausea and vomiting; and unable to void urine must be reported and a plan of care documented.
4.4.8 When the patient is stable and all documentation complete the patient will be transferred to step down 2 or the main wards.
4.4.9 Delays of a patient in recovery for more than 20 minutes will be recorded and reported.
4.4.10 All medication given must be recorded and signed on the prescription chart before the patient leave stage 1 recovery.
4.4.11 Patients requiring admissions to the main wards will be transferred from Recovery
4.4.12 Patients admitted to TADSU who are having surgery within the Main Theatre complex but who are on a day case pathway will be transferred back to TADSU.
TADSU Step down Recovery day case pathway
4.5.1 Patients will continue to be monitored according to individual post operative requirements.
4.5.2 Appropriate early intervention for any adverse post operative event to prevent delay in discharge.
4.5.3 Post-operative refreshment will be provided. Hot meals will not be available on TADSU.
4.5.4 Patients who fail to meet the day surgery criteria post surgery may be transferred to the if appropriate or a main ward.
Day Surgery Step down Recovery on the DSU
4.6.1 Patients will continue to be monitored according to individual post-operative requirements.
4.6.2 Appropriate early intervention for any adverse post-operative event to prevent delay in discharge.
4.6.3 Post-operative refreshment will be provided. Hot meals will be available.
4.6.4 Patients who fail to meet the day surgery criteria post surgery should be transferred to a main ward. The operating surgeon or consultant must be immediately notified.
Day Surgery Discharge
4.7.1 Prior to discharge the named nurse will assess the patient to ensure that the discharge criteria have been met (PADS). The following must be in place before the patient is discharged:
Post Anaesthetic Discharge Scoring System

table_items.text: 2 BP and Pulse within 20% of pre op. baseline
2 Steady gait, no dizziness or meets pre op level
2 Minimal, successfully treated with oral meds.
Acceptable to the patient. Controllable by oral meds. Consistent with expected pain Pain acceptable?
2 Minimal, does not require dressing change
1 BP and Pulse within 20-40% of pre op. baseline
1 Moderate, successfully treated With im. Meds.
1 Moderate, up to 2 dressing changes required
0 BP and Pulse >40% of pre op. baseline
0 Severe more than three dressing changes required

data.text: Maximal score = 10. Patients scoring >/= 9 are fit for discharge;
A responsible adult must escort and transport the patient; verbal and written post- operative information is given to the patient in the presence of a carer;
Patient should be prescribed medication if applicable;
EDL Discharge summary has to be made for every patient;
Community arrangements made if required;
Follow up instructions have to be given to patient;
Contact information is given to patient.
4.7.2 Patients will receive a post operative phone call by a trained nurse 48hours post surgery to audit the patient experience. This process will be used for Audit purposes.

4.7.3 For patients who require a 23hour overnight stay for medical, surgical or social reasons the bed manager will be contacted to facilitate admission. If necessary, the appropriate surgical speciality will arrange a bed prior to surgery.
Relatives and Carers
4.8.1 In TADSU Recovery within Main Theatre there is a facility for relatives to remain with the patient in the waiting room only.
4.8.2 A breast feeding mother having day surgery will require a responsible adult to stay and care for the baby until the mother is recovered sufficiently to resume care.
4.8.3 The patients relative / carer will supply a telephone number to enable the unit staff to contact them following surgery. The TADSU will also provide the relative/carer with the unit number.
Private patients
4.9.1 There are no special facilities for private patients on the TADSU, DSU or the Braintree Unit; however, they can be accommodated.
4.9.2 The Consultant's Secretary in liaison with the Private Patient's Office will inform the TADSU / DSU / Braintree Unit Team if any patients are scheduled for surgery there.
Support of the Pain Service from TADSU (Refer to Appendix 7)
4.10.1 The TADSU / DSU will provide the theatre and ward staff to facilitate The pain lists.
4.10.2 The patient will be prepared for pain clinic as per the admission protocol using the pain document.
4.10.3 The patient will be reviewed by the Pain consultant who will mark the operation site if applicable and ensure the consent form is correct and signed.
4.10.4 The patient will either be walked to theatre or transferred on a trolley if required to the designated procedure room.
4.10.5 The patient will be checked into theatre using the WHO surgical safety checklist.
4.10.6 The transfer and positioning of the patient on the X-ray trolley will be undertaken in accordance with health and safety guidelines.
4.10.7 The patient will be monitored according to the Royal College of Anaesthetist guidelines for a local anaesthetic.
Key Relationships
Anaesthetic Assessment Unit
Assessment of all patients undergoing general anaesthetic.
Catering
Supply of milk, refreshments for patients whose stay is over 4 hours.
Domestic Services
Provision of cleaners in the evening to clean theatres, ward and administrative areas.
Physiotherapy
Provision of support service for orthopaedic cases.
Pharmacy & Medications
5.5.1 Provision of advice regarding drugs and maintenance of stock levels from pharmacy.
5.5.2 Patients hand in their medication to the ward nurse, which is then returned to them when they are discharged or transferred to a main ward.
5.5.3 Patients own medication is stored in a locked cupboard.
5.5.4 The storage and return of patients medication is documented in the patient's notes.
5.5.5 Doctors from the primary team should prescribe regular medication.
5.5.6 TTA's are prescribed on an individual basis which should be supplied from the DSU Ward stock cupboard.
Security Requirements
5.6.1 TADSU, DSU, Theatre and anaesthetic areas are accessed via swipe card.
5.6.2 All pharmacy stock are contained within locked a locked cupboard which requires swipe card access; with the exception of iv fluid which can be stored within the stock area.

5.6.3 The reception area is manned in TADSU from 0700 to 15:00 and 07:00 to 15:00 in DSU. When reception is closed access to the department can be obtained by ringing a door bell to notify the ward staff that the escorts have arrived to collect the patients.
5.6.4 On the DSU the main doors to the unit will be locked automatically at 20:30, access to the unit is gained by ringing the door bell.
5.6.5 All staff will be required to wear identity badges.
5.6.6 On TADSU notes are locked in the reception office at night. On the Day Stay Unit notes will be locked in the Medical Records Satellite Room.
Medical Records Flow (Refer to Appendix 8)
5.7.1 All patients' medical records will be managed confidentially at all ties and stored in a locked office when not in use.
5.7.2 All movement of patient records will be accurately tracked in accordance with the trusts case notes tracking policy.
5.7.3 All new documentation will be secured into the folder prior to it leaving the department
Staffing
Staff Levels
(Refer to Appendix 9)
6.1.1 TADSU, DSU and Braintree Unit has a lead Band 7 practitioner who will manage the service on a daily basis working with a motivated multidisciplinary team.
6.1.2 The TADSU, Braintree unit and the DSU incorporating the Reception, ward and theatre areas providing a service from 07:00 Monday to 21:30 on a Friday.
6.1.3 The reception staff work within reception from 07:00 to 15:00 but this is flexible to meet the needs of the service.

6.1.4 Theatre staff and recovery are allocated to an operating session which may cover a morning 08:30-12:30, afternoon 13:30-17:30 or all day session 08:30-17:30 based a upon clinical skills and surgical speciality.
6.1.5 A Theatre team for a GA list will consist of:
A Scrub Nurse;
A Circulating Nurse;
1 - 2 HCA's;
An ODP;
Recovery Staff.
6.1.6 A Theatre team for an LA list will consist of:
A Scrub Nurse;
A Circulating Nurse;
1 - 2 HCA's;
An ODP / trained nurse to monitor the patient.
6.1.7 The Anaesthetist designated to the list should be a Consultant or a Registrar supported by an onsite Consultant.

6.1.8 Ward staff are allocated to each theatre session to care for the patients pre and post operatively which may cover a morning, afternoon or all day session based a upon clinical skills and surgical speciality. The ward area in TADSU is covered from 07:30 to 21:00 hours to provide pre and post-operative care and in the DSU is covered from Monday 07:00 to 14:00 hours Saturday providing 23-hour care.
6.1.9 A ward team for each theatre session will consist of:
A Trained Nurse;
A HCA 2 or HCA 3.
6.1.10 All surgical specialities are led within the department by Band 6's and are supported by Band 5, HCA 3 and HCA 2.
6.1.11 Specialist Theatre staff to undertake specialist surgery involving laser and laparoscopic and ophthalmic work.
6.1.12 The Majority of the TADSU / DSU / Braintree Unit team is multi skilled and will rotate through the department if required, providing a well trained, flexible, efficient, effective workforce.

6.1.13 TADSU will open from 0700 to 21:00 Monday to Friday. The DSU will be open from 07:00 Monday to 21:30 on Friday. Braintree Unit will be open from 07:00 to 21:00 Monday to Friday. A 24 hour information service for the post-operative patient will be provided.
Training and Education
6.2.1 Medical, nursing and staff in training are welcome on the TADSU / DSU on the provision that their numbers or inexperience does not interfere with the smooth running of the unit.
6.2.2 Visits that include a teaching element must be made by prior arrangement with the lead Nurse and the operating list adjusted accordingly.
6.2.3 All new staff will have a mentor and a set of competencies to complete within an agreed time frame.
6.2.4 All experience staff will act as preceptors to develop junior staffs' competencies.
6.2.5 Staff will be expected to update their Mandatory training as required by trust policy.
6.2.6 Training sessions will be laid on audit days to facilitate mandatory updates.
Equipment Requirements
X-ray trolleys for pain service x 3;
Image Intensifier for Pain Service x 1;
Wheelchairs x 2, frames x 1;
operating trolleys x 60;
Diathermy machines x 2;
Bipolar diathermy machine in ophthalmics x 1;
Microscopes x 2;
Phaco machines x 2;
Syringe pumps x 3;
Laser machine x 1 x Green light, 1 x holmium;
Laparoscopic equipment x 2 stack systems;
THD machine x 1;
Suction apparatus x 5 portable, 31 fixed;
Fax machine x 1 in Reception;
Printers x 2 in reception and Rest Room;
Scan track systems x 5;
Resuscitation trolleys x 2 adult, x 2 child.
Contingency
There are processes in relation to a variety of contingency issues as follows:
Always report issues to the senior staff available i.e. Ward Sister, General Manager and director on call if appropriate;
Out of hours contact the Duty Matron, Service Co-ordinator and /or On-call Manager;
Always identify the senior staff available to assist with the problem;
Contact others as required, security, porters, and switchboard.
Should a problem be identified in relation to a piece of equipment failure (such as a
ward held Syringe pump) the contingency would be that the piece of equipment is
removed from use. Staff must be made aware of where the nearest available piece of equipment is located. Follow points 1-4 above and note what actions are taken.
Contact BME in order to repair faulty equipment and/ or seek a replacement.
Power Failure – back-up generator will allow for any cases to be completed. There after only emergency cases will be undertaken.
HSDU steam failure – Liaise with HSDU, prioritising cases.
If DSU is used as contingency ward for emergency admissions, elective operations will not be performed with prior executive approval.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to commit to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 11)
Auditing this Policy

Auditing will be carried out via post-operative telephone calls made  hours after discharge. All information will be treated confidentially and any issues dealt with according to trust policy and in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Theatre and Outpatient's Division annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes.
Breaches - all breaches of the policy to be reported on a risk event form using the DATIX system on line.
Responsibilities
(Refer to Appendix 10)
The TADSU / DSU will be managed within the Theatre and Outpatients Division and must therefore follow the Theatre and Outpatient's Division objectives and targets.

The TADSU / DSU has a dedicated Clinical Lead of the Day Surgery Service, providing leadership, ensuring consistent guidelines and policies are adopted across all specialities, and to lead on developments and innovations and clinical governance.

The TADSU / DSU has one Senior Nurse in place to support the Clinical Director in developing protocols and practice and leading nursing practice. The Senior Nurse will be responsible for the day to day running of the unit.
The TADSU / DSU waiting lists are managed by the respective specialties.
Implementation and communication
Patient information is found on the intranet and on line.
Communication of implementation will occur via trust communications and audit Meeting and emails to all staff concerned with Day Surgery.
References
Coates, Tracy and Guckian Fisher, Mona, 2008.Staffing for patients in the perioperative setting. Harrogate: Association forPerioperative Practice.

Department of Health, 2007. Facilities for day surgery units (HBN 10-02). London:Department of Health. Available at: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/day-surgery-facilities-buildings-guidance
Association of Anaesthetists of Great Britain and Ireland and British Association of Day Surgery, 2011. Day case and short stay surgery: 2, Anaesthesia, 66(5), pp417-
British Association of Day Surgery Directory of Procedures, 2019 BADS Directory of recommended Day and Short stay surgical procedures. 6th ed. London:BADS.
Appendix 1
The Selection Process for Day Surgery

Following  referral  from  the  outpatient's  department  by  the  surgeon  using  the  following defined criteria, patients selected for day surgery will be referred to the unit where a detailed pre assessment will be carried out.

The nurse-led pre-assessment clinics are trained in this role and have the option to refer the patient to the pre-assessment consultant if a problem is identified that could potentially increase the risk during anaesthetic or surgical intervention.
When Patients are referred for day surgery it is essential to ensure that:
The procedure is suitable
The risk of complications from surgery and anaesthesia are minimised
Admission to an in-patient bed following day surgery is prevented
Patients are adequately supported after discharge home
Exclusion criteria as outlined for each unit (Refer to point 3.5)
Effective patient selection will
Prevent patient cancellations on the day of surgery
Improve the holistic family centred patient care
Ensure adequate support and education for pre and post-operative care
Maximise the use of the operating sessions
Contribute to the over all efficiency of the day unit
Increase patient satisfaction
Selection Criteria
The  American  society  of  Anaesthesiologists  (ASA)  classification  status  will  be  used  to assess a patient's suitability.
It is essential that patients have support from careers and a means of contacting the hospital should the need arise.
Social factors
(a) The patient must understand the planned procedure and postoperative care and consent
to day surgery.
(b) Following most procedures under general anaesthesia, a responsible adult should escort the patient home and provide support for the first 24 hours.
(c) The patient's domestic circumstances should be appropriate for postoperative care. Medical factors
(a) Fitness for a procedure should relate to the patient's health as determined at pre- operative assessment and not limited by arbitrary limits such as ASA status, age or BMI
(b) Patients with stable chronic disease such as diabetes, asthma or epilepsy are often better managed as day cases because of minimal disruption to their daily routine.

(c) Obesity per se is not a contraindication to day surgery as even morbidly obese patients can be safely managed in expert hands, with appropriate resources. In addition, obese patients benefit from the short-duration anaesthetic techniques and early mobilization associated with day surgery. However please refer to exclusion criteria for DSU and BU
Surgical factors
(a) The procedure should not carry a significant risk of serious complications requiring immediate medical attention (haemorrhage, cardiovascular instability).
(b) Postoperative symptoms must be controllable by the use of a combination of oral medication and local anaesthetic techniques.
(c) The procedure should not prohibit the patient from resuming oral intake within a few hours.
(d) Patients should usually be able to mobilize before discharge although full mobilization is not always essential.

Date for Anaesthetic Pre Assessment

Patient advised of date of Surgery within 18 weeks

Medical Records Flow

Regular updates to ensure notes obtained

Any unavailable notes may result in cancellation of patient

A change to an existing policy
A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Who benefits from this change and how?
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change? b) If so, with whom?

data.text: Preliminary analysis completed by:
